qas.question: Who is the city's 2nd largest employer?
Which non-profit non-governmental organization is located in Ann Arbor?
How many researchers does the University of Michigan expect to hire?
What pharmaceutical company was Ann Arbor's largest employer?
What company announced it would close operations by the end of 2007?
What month in 2007 did the University of Michigan Board of Regents approve the purchase of the facilities?
Who automobile manufactures has a Fuel Emissions Laboratory in Ann Arbor?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Pfizer<b3_0/><a0_0/>, once the city's second largest employer, operated a large pharmaceutical research facility on the northeast side of Ann Arbor. On 22 January 2007, <b4_0>Pfizer<b4_0/> announced it would close operations in Ann Arbor by the end of 2008. The facility was previously operated by Warner-Lambert and, before that, Parke-Davis. In <b5_0>December<b5_0/> 2008, the University of Michigan Board of Regents approved the purchase of the facilities, and the university anticipates hiring <a2_0>2,000<a2_0/> researchers and staff during the next 10 years. The city is the home of other research and engineering centers, including those of Lotus Engineering, General Dynamics and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Other research centers sited in the city are the United States Environmental Protection Agency's National Vehicle and Fuel Emissions Laboratory and the <b6_0>Toyota<b6_0/> Technical Center. The city is also home to <a1_0>National Sanitation Foundation International<a1_0/> (NSF International), the nonprofit non-governmental organization that develops generally accepted standards for a variety of public health related industries and subject areas.
